results.title: Les Cousins = the Cousins
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Paul Wagner and Ajym Films
results.brief_description:
Simple, good-hearted country cousin Charles comes to study at the Sorbonne in Paris where he stays at the luxury apartment of Paul, his cynical city cousin. Charles works hard but fails his exams, Paul doesn’t but passes and gets Charles’s girl. Chabrol’s second feature film re-unites Jean-Claude Brialy and Gerard Blain, the two lead actors from his debut feature, ‘Le Beau Serge’. Paul (Brialy) is a hedonistic and confident Parisian student living in his uncle’s fashionable inner city flat. He spends his time drinking, carousing, sleeping with a variety of female friends and playing the role of matchmaker for his friends, arranging trysts in an ongoing merry go round of bed partners. He is an emotionally remote and decadent man, adhering to a dubious moral code, who approaches his friends love lives with devilish detachment. Charles (Blain) is his naive country cousin, a dedicated student, who stays with Paul whilst studying for his law exams. When Charles is introduced to Paul’s swinging set, he instantaneously falls for Florence, a beautiful woman who is intrigued by Charles’ innocence. Paul is perturbed as he observes the attraction between the two and the respect that Charles displays for Florence. A clash is inevitable as the rivalry for Florences affection grows. The contrast between the two main characters morality is acute, especially in their attitudes toward women. A dramatic study of class conflict and personal responsibility ‘Les Cousins’ is a riveting and perverse study of decadent Parisian student life. The City of Lights is captured by Decae’s camera as if seen through the amazed eyes of Charles. The film won the Best Film award at the Berlin Film Festival in 1959. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Paul Wagner ; director, Claude Chabrol ; writers, Claude Chabrol, Paul Gegauff ; photography, Henri Decae ; music, Paul Misraki ; editing, Jacques Gaillard.
Cast: Gerard Blain, Jean-Claude Brialy, Juliette Mayniel, Claude Cerval, Genevieve Cluny, Guy Decomble, Stephane Audran.

results.title: Le Voyage du Pere = the Father's Trip
results.creator_credit: Denys de la Patelliere and Raymond Danon
results.brief_description:
At his wife’s request, Monsieur Quentin, leaves his farm to go to city in order to convince his daughter to attend a family gathering. Once in town, he discovers that his daughter has become a prostitute.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Denys de la Patelliere ; writers, Denys de la Patelliere, Pascal Jardin ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Fernandel, Philippe Noiret, Lilli Palmer, Michel Auclair, Laurent Terzieff, Madeleine Robinson, Rosy Varte.

results.title: Les Creatures = the Creatures
results.creator_credit: Agnes Varda, Mag Bodard and Philippe Dussart
results.brief_description:
A novelist and his pregnant wife go on holidays after he is horribly scarred during an automobile accident. He uses the time to complete his new novel and the local residents become models for his characters.

Credits: Producers, Mag Bodard, Philippe Dussart ; director, Agnes Varda ; writer, Agnes Varda ; photography, Willy Kurant, William Lubtchansky ; music, Pierre Barbaud.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Catherine Deneuve, Eva Dahlbeck, Britta Patterson, Jacques Charrier, Lucien Bodard, Ursula Kubler, Nino Castelnuovo.

results.title: L'idiot = the Idiot
results.brief_description:
Russian prince Muichkine returns to St. Petersburg after a stay in a Swiss mental hospital. Blissfully unaware of the greater social problems of his country, the prince believes that love and goodness reign supreme around him. He becomes betrothed to an innocent young girl while trying to save a less-innocent woman from her downfall. Jealousy and his own naivete conjoin to bring about an unimaginable tragedy. ‘L’idiot’ was remade in Japan by Akira Kurosawa (1951) and in Russia by Ivan Pyriev (1958).

Credits: Producer, Sacha Gordine ; director, Georges Lampin ; writers, Charles Spaak, Georges Raewsky ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Maurice Thiriet, V. de Butzow.
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Edwige Feuillere, Lucien Coedel, Nathalie Nattier, Marguerite Moreno, Jean Debucourt, Sylvie.

results.title: Une Si Jolie Petite Plage = Such a Pretty Little Beach
results.brief_description:
Pierre registers at a dismal hotel in a desolate seaside resort in Normandy. He had worked there as a kitchen hand some years before and run off with a famous singer, who has just been found dead. He is supected by a mysterious fellow guest of having committed a crime of passion. Instead of finding peace in the village were he grew up, Pierre is driven to desparation by the grotesque pettiness of the local townsfolk, the duplicity of friends and so-called loved ones and the relentlessly rotten weather.

Credits: Producer, Emile Darbon ; director, Yves Allegret ; writer, Jacques Sigurd ; photography, Henri Alekan ; music, Maurice Thiriet.
Cast: Madeleine Robinson, Gerard Philippe, Jane Marken, Jean Servais, Julien Carette, Mona Dol, Andre Valmy.

results.title: Ce Cher Victor = that Dear Victor
results.brief_description:
Two elderly friends, sensitive Anselme and blustering Victor, decide to set up housekeeping together in order to save money. Although the men have been friends for 40 years, this new arrangement brings out their different sensibilities and puts a lot of stress on their friendship.

Credits: Producer, Yves Witner ; director, Robin Davis ; writer, Patrick Laurent, Robin Davis ; photography, Yves Lafaye, Philippe Rousselot ; music, Bernard Gerard ; editor, Jose Pinheiro
Cast: Bernard Blier, Jacques Dufilho, Alida Valli, Jacqueline Doyen, Philippe Castelli, Jacques Rispal.

results.title: Bapteme
results.creator_credit: Rene Feret, Eric Trotta and Louis Wipf
results.brief_description:
In 1935, near Bethune (northern France), Aline marries Pierre instead of the man who had been chosen for her. After their honeymoon, Aline replaces her mother running a small cafe while Pierre works on fairs and markets. Largely inspired by the real story of his parents, Rene Feret’s film chronicles the ups and downs of a working class couple from the 1930’s to the 1960’s.

Credits: Producers, Eric Trotta, Louis Wipf ; director, Rene Feret ; writer, Rene Feret ; photography, Pierre Lhomme ; music, Frederic Chopin, Evelyne Stroh.
Cast: Valerie Stroh, Jean-Yves Berteloot, Jacques Bonnaffe, Pierre-Alain Chapuis, Edith Scob, Elsa Zylberstein.

results.title: La Collectionneuse = the Collector Girl
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Barbet Schroeder and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
Feeling vaguely abandoned as his girlfriend has gone to London, Adrian, a dilettante philosopher, goes to stay at a friend’s villa on the outskirts of St. Tropez. Daniel, an avant-garde artist, and Haydee, a sweetly amoral nymphette who sleeps with a different boy every night, are there also. As the collector of the title, she causes disarray in the two men who decide it is their duty to resist her advances - an intellectual rather than physical moral superiority. It is Adrian, frustrated and chastened, who finally fulfills the moral outline of the series, by hopefully planning a reconciliation with his girlfriend. ‘La Collectionneuse’ was the first feature Rohmer made in 35mm and colour. This is the fourth installement of Rohmer’s ‘Six Moral Tales’.

Credits: Producers, Georges de Beauregard, Barbet Schroeder ; director, Eric Rohmer ; writer, Eric Rohmer ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; music, Les Blossom Toes, Giorgio Gomeslky.
Cast: Patrick Bauchau, Haydee Politoff, Daniel Pommereulle, Seymour Hertzberg.

results.title: Caroline Cherie = Dear Caroline
results.creator_credit: Richard Pottier, Alain Poire and Paul Cadeac
results.brief_description:
Caroline de Bievres celebrates her 16th birthday on 14 July 1789. While the Parisians storm the Bastille, Caroline experiences love with Gaston de Sallanches. Sent to Paris by her parents, she discovers that Gaston is already married.

Credits: Producer, Alain Poire, Paul Cadeac ; director, Richard Pottier ; writer, Jean Anouilh ; photography, Maurice Barry ; music, Georges Auric ; art director, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Martine Carol, Jacques Dacqmine, Pierre Cressoy, Jacques Clancy, Marie Dea, Daniele Seller, Paul Bernard, Alfred Adam, Raymond Souplex, Marthe Mercadier, Nadine Alari, Yvonne de Bray, Marie Dea, Olivier Hussenot.

results.title: J'ai Epouse Une Ombre = I Married a Dead Man
results.brief_description:
Helene is 8 months pregnant when she is abandoned by Frank, her companion. Lonely and desperate she boards the first train heading south. Aboard, she meets vineyard heir Bertrand Meyrand and his wife Patricia, also 8 months pregnant. During the night, the train is derailed. Bertrand and Patricia die during the accident. When Helene wakes up at the hospital, she realises that everyone mistakes her for Patricia, including Bertrand’s parents who offer her shelter at their wine growing property. Helene settles uncomfortably in her new family, until the day Frank comes back to blackmail her. The plot is based on a story by Cornell Woolrich and was filmed twice before as ‘No Man of Her Own’ in 1932 and 1949 in the U.S.A. In 1996 it was remade again as the romantic comedy ‘Mrs. Winterbourne’.

Credits: Producer, Alain Sarde ; director, Robin Davis ; writers, Robin Davis, Patrick Laurent ; photography, Bernard Zitzerman ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Nathalie Baye, Francis Huster, Richard Bohringer, Madeleine Robinson, Guy Trejean, Victoria Abril, Veronique Genest.
